Introduction
This is the manual for the &Semigroups; package for &GAP; version &VERSION;. &Semigroups; &VERSION; is a distant descendant of the
http://schmidt.nuigalway.ie/monoid/index.html by Goetz Pfeiffer, Steve A. Linton, Edmund F. Robertson, and Nik Ruskuc.
&Semigroups; &VERSION; contains efficient methods for creating semigroups, monoids, inverse semigroups and their ideals, calculating their Green's structure, size, elements, group of units, minimal ideal, and testing membership, finding the inverses of a regular element, and factorizing elements over the generators, and much more; see Chapters , , and . There are methods for testing if semigroups satisfy particular properties, such as if they are regular, simple, inverse, completely regular, and a variety of further properties; see Chapter .
There are methods for finding: congruences of semigroups, the normalizer of a semigroup in a permutation group (as given in ), the maximal subsemigroups of a finite semigroup (based on ), smaller degree partial permutation representations (based on ) and the character table of an inverse semigroup. There are functions for producing pictures of the Green's structure of a semigroup, and for drawing graphical representations of the elements of certain semigroups; see Chapter .
Many standard examples of semigroups and classes of semigroups are provided; see Section . &Semigroups; also provides functions to read and write collections of transformations, partial permutations, and bipartitions to a file; see and .
There are functions in &Semigroups; to define and manipulate free inverse semigroups and free bands; this part of the package was written by Julius Jonušas; see Chapters and .
There are three fundamental types of algorithms in the &Semigroups; package, those for semigroups of:
transformations, partial permutations, bipartitions, and subsemigroups of regular Rees 0-matrix semigroups over groups. When applied to semigroups with large subgroups these are the most efficient methods in the &Semigroups; package. For example, the complexity of computing, say, the size of a transformation semigroup that happens to be a group, is the same as the complexity of the Schreier-Sims Algorithm (polynomial in the number of points acted on by the transformations) for a permutation group.
The algorithms of this type are described in . In theory, these algorithms can be applied to compute any subsemigroup of a regular semigroup. For details of how to extend &Semigroups; see . We refer to semigroups to which the algorithms in can be applied as acting semigroups. See Section for further details.
partitioned binary relations as defined in , and matrices over the following semirings:
the Boolean semiring \{0,1\} where 0 + 0 = 0, 0 + 1 = 1 + 1 = 1 + 0 = 1, and 1\cdot 0 = 0 \cdot 0 = 0 \cdot 1 = 0
fields of prime order;
the max-plus semiring of natural numbers and negative infinity \mathbb{N}\cup \{-\infty\} with operations max and plus;
the min-plus semiring of natural numbers and infinity \mathbb{N}\cup \{\infty\} with operations min and plus;
the tropical max-plus semiring \{-\infty, 0, 1, \ldots, t\} for some threshold t with operations max and plus;
the tropical min-plus semiring \{0, 1, \ldots, t, \infty\} for some threshold t with operations min and plus;
the tropical min-plus semiring \mathbb{N}_{t,p} = \{0, 1, \ldots, t, t + 1, \ldots, t + p - 1\} for some threshold t and period p under addition and mutliplication modulo the congruence t = t + p.
A version of the Froidure-Pin Algorithm (written in C++) is used to compute semigroups of these types. The implementation in &Semigroups; performs at least as well as the C programme by Jean-Eric Pin. This algorithm out performs the algorithms for acting semigroups when applied to semigroups with small (trivial) subgroups, and is also used for semigroups to which the algorithms described in do not apply. It is possible to specify which methods should be applied to a given semigroup; see Section .
any other semigroup in &GAP;. A version of the Froidure-Pin Algorithm (written in &GAP; kernel code) is used to compute semigroups of this type. Mostly due to the way that &GAP; handles memory, this implementation is approximately 4 times slower than the C++ implementation when applied to semigroups of the types given in 2. However, this implementation has the advantage that it can be applied to any semigroup defined in &GAP;.
Minor note of caution: &Semigroups; contains different methods for some &GAP; library functions, and so you might notice that &GAP; behaves differently when &Semigroups; is loaded. For more details about semigroups in &GAP; or Green's relations in particular, see or .
